PROJECT PREPARATORY TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
 
A.  Justification 
 
1.  The proposed Gansu Jinta Concentrated Solar Power Project will construct a 50 MW 
CSP plant in Gansu Province in the PRC. It is included in the country programming mission held 
in Manila in December 2012 as standby 2013 and firm in 2014. Considering the readiness of the 
Project, early commencement of a project preparatory technical assistance (TA) is required to (i) 
conduct the due diligence on relevant aspects of the proposed project (para. 14, main text), (ii) 
technical guidance on technical risks assessment and development of mitigation measures for 
preliminary and detailed design and preparation of technical specification of tender documents, 
and  (iii)  familiarize  the  executing  and  implementing  agencies  with  ADB’s  procurement 
procedure, disbursement procedure, and environment and social safeguards requirement.

C.  Cost Estimate and Proposed Financing Arrangement  
 
3.  The TA is estimated to cost $650,000 equivalent, of which $550,000 will be financed on 
a  grant  basis  from  ADB’s  Technical  Assistance  Special  Fund  (TASF-other  sources).  The 
government  will  provide  counterpart  support  in  the  form  of  counterpart  staff,  office 
accommodations,  studies,  reports,  data  and  other  in-kind  contributions.  The  value  of

16  Appendix 5 
D.  Consulting Services 
 
4.  The TA implementation will use a two parts approach to match the tight implementation 
schedule of the Project. Due to readiness of the Project, recruitment of individual consultants for 
Part  1  (detailed  due  diligence,  see  para  14,  main  text)  is  more  appropriate  for  the  quick 
mobilization  of  consultants  and  more  cost-effective  than  recruitment  of  consulting  firms  to 
perform  the  assignments.  Nine  individual  consultants  (three  international  for  a  total  of  7.5 
person-months and six national for a total of 12.0 person-months) will be recruited for Part 1.1  
 
5.  Part  2  will:  (a)  assess  any  potential  technical  risks  in  system  design,  construction 
supervision, and operation and maintenance, recommend any mitigation measures and conduct 
training for the counterpart engineers to mitigate those risks; (b) review and recommend for 
improvement of the system design and optimization of system configuration; and (c) assist the 
implementing agency in finalizing the procurement plan and tender documents.  To complete 
these activities, about 7.5 person-months of consulting services inputs from a team of various 
international technical experts will be required. However, since the proposed project entails 
innovative and first-of-its-kind solar energy technology, required types of expert, detailed TOR, 
and consultants selection methods (e.g. individual consultants vs. consulting firm) can only be  
firmed up after a rigorous due diligence under Part 1. All consultants under Part 1 and Part 2 will 
be engaged by ADB in accordance with the Guidelines on the Use of Consultants (2010, as 
amended from time to time). The proceeds of the TA will be disbursed in line with ADB's 
Technical Assistance Disbursement Handbook (2010, as amended from time to time). The 
required experts (consultants) and person-months are indicated in Table A5.3.
